name: Hanna Saad
comment info:
Hanna Saad
Mr. Hibino
Statistics
Sep 16, 2021

1.What do you notice?
As Quarantine progressed and more people stayed home, people connected more by texting, Video calls and phone calls. Exercising decreased probably due to gyms closing and not being able to go to the gym so people worked out at home. Self care decreased due to everyone being home and not going out as much.
2. What do you wonder?
Why would older people not take care of themselves more when they have a lot more free time? Why would 15-20 year olds exercise less when they have more free time? 
I had so much more free time with covid that I would go mountain biking everyday and spend more time hanging out with friends in person outdoors (limiting chances of catching covid). Why didnt many other people take advantage of this free time.
3. What impact does this have on you and your community?
The impact was huge on my community because people weren't going out as often and the only stores that were open were “essential” (gas stations, Super Markets, costco). My town was also a ghost town for a good while and there were less cars on the streets. 
4. What's going on in this graph? Write a catchy headline that captures the graph's main idea.

name: Tony
comment info:
Things are slowly returning to the old normal, but from the graph, we see that some of our own habits remain unchanged from during the pandemic.
The first thing I noticed was the increase in time spent on video chats and messages. What surprised me was that it had not decreased during all this time. It made sense, perhaps during the beginning of the pandemic and quarantine, when regulations were high. Back then, video chats were the only way you could communicate with your friends. But now, most students have gotten their vaccines, and the younger ones who haven’t got them don't need them to see friends. Face-to-face is now common in day-to-day life, and students already spend 6 hours a day interacting with others. After school, they hang out at the park to play basketball. They don’t exactly prefer to video chat with each other; at least, I can’t imagine why they would.
Even though we’re moving away from the secluded society which was the result of coronavirus, we have not changed our habits. Maybe it’s because we’re lazy, maybe it’s because we find that our new habits suit us better. Whatever the reason, we’re changing and developing as a society, making new adaptations as time passes. Perhaps we’ll never go back to the old normal, but instead stay at an ongoing normal.
Headline: Are We as Adaptable as Our Environment?

name: Ashlyn
comment info:
1. I notice that texting, making phone calls, and video chatting for all ages increased. This must be due to the fact that people had more downtime and they wanted to keep themselves occupied. As well as this, I noticed that for people aged 25+, the amount of time people spent exercising also increased. However, for people aged 15-24, the amount of time exercising decreased. On the other hand, the opposite occurred for grooming. With this being said, people aged 15-24 years old spent more time grooming than people aged 25+. 
2. I wonder why the amount of time spent exercising for people aged 15-24 decreased because I felt as if I spent more time exercising during the pandemic. However, the graph shows that we spent more time on our phones instead. I also wonder why the amount of time spent grooming with people aged 25+ decreased. I would think that it would have increased considering that these people had more time to do so. 
3. This impacts me and my community because we all experienced this pandemic together and noticed changes in our daily lives. It is interesting to visualize the amount spent on everyday tasks like these. 
4. In this graph, different age groups were being studied to see how much time was spent on their phones, exercising and grooming. A catchy headline that captures the graph's main idea would be “How did COVID change the way we spend our daily lives?”

name: Hayley Pizur
comment info:
1.) What do you notice?
I noticed immediately that the amount of time spent texting or making calls or video chats steadily increased for all age groups while grooming for a majority of the older age groups plummeted. 
2.) What do you wonder? 
I wonder the reasoning for the slight decrease in exercise by the younger generation with the new options available in gyms and online while the elder population has exercised more frequently. 
3.) How does this relate to you or your community?
The pandemic-related quarantine created a drastic change in acceptable phone usage in comparison to much more in important livelihood practices, including exercise and bodily grooming. The corona virus in addition to the unhealthy practices occurring in the midst of 2020 allowed for the negative aspects that correlated with the requirement to remain home. 
4.) What is going on in this graph? Create a catchy headline that captures the graphs’ main idea. 
This graph accurately portrays the average non-work/non-school time dedicated to cell phone usage, exercise, and hygiene from May 2019 to December 2020 for all ages. It is evident within that graph that texting increased across all subjects, and the fair majority of individuals failed or lessened their extent of grooming and exercise. 
Catchy headline: The Health Experts Lied

name: Ary
comment info:
1. The graphs are of average free time spent per day by age. They show the difference in minutes from 2019 to 2020. The four age groups are 15-24, 25-44, 45-64, and 65+. For all age groups time spent texting, phone calls, and videos calls increased. For ages 15-24 time spent exercising decreased by five minutes, but for the other groups it increased by 4 or 5 minutes. Grooming decreased for all groups except 15-24, which had a small increase. 

2. I wonder why the time spent texting and on phone and video calls is so low. From my experience and observation people spend much longer than 15 minutes a day texting or on calls. Maybe the number is so low because it only counts communication and not social media. I also wonder why ages 15-24 exercised less. Being at home more seems to have affected exercise time of very young people differently than everyone else, according to this graph. I also wonder why ages 15-24 spent slightly more time grooming. This could be because people those ages still had to be on video calls or even in person for school, so they still maintained their appearances.

3. This impacts my community because the pandemic did affect how we spend our time. For my community the increase in time spent texting and on calls and decrease in time exercising generally applies. The almost no change in time spent grooming also makes sense because we still had to go to school.

4. “The Pandemic Redistributes Our Free Time”

Great noticings and wonderings. 

These are called slope graphs.  Wonder why?  But, here there is something misleading about the slopes.  Do you see it? 

To find out about how the data were collected, search online for BLS American Time Use Survey methodology.  Read how national data can be collected and analyzed.

name: Ami
comment info:
What do you notice? 

I notice that my age group (15-24) increased in online communication by significantly more time than other age groups. Also, my age group has decreased in exercise whereas every other age group has increased in that area. Lastly, my age group was the only group to increase in grooming, which shows how we're dedicating more time to self-care, at least in that arena. 

What do you wonder? 

I wonder why my age group increased in grooming yet decreased in exercise, as self-care usually includes both grooming and exercise -- these two factors are usually linked. Furthermore, I wonder why other age groups decreased in grooming, perhaps because they had to work even more at home whereas school time is typically constant. 

How does this relate to you and your community? 

It's interesting to see how my age group, late teens and early adults, have an increased electronics use and on the whole, are dedicating less time to self-care despite the greater amount of free time due to less homework and fewer commitments (on average). Furthermore, I feel like other age groups are more readily able to purchase goods/services, which may have led to the increase in exercise (for instance, they can buy a Peloton bike) amongst other age groups. The changes in grooming amongst other groups make sense because they don't need to look as good for work at home, but grooming in our age group is still a mystery to me. 

Catchy headline: Gen Z is truly the digital generation.

comment info: This graph depicts the trend of certain activities in certain age groups in 2019 and 2020. I think that Covid-19 is a huge factor in many of the results. For all age groups except 15-24, exercise increased likely due to an increase in free time. For teens and young adults, however, exercising decreased. name: James Molenhouse
comment info: Something interesting about these graphs, is that no one seems to understand them. People in this comment section seem to think that 15-24 year olds increasing their time texting, using phone calls, and video calls, means increased time looking at social media. Although that could be true, the first graph mentions nothing about social media use increase. Beyond that people also seem to think that texting, phone calls, and video calls means increased phone usage. However, the graph is not looking at phone usage. Although phone calls do of course mean increased phone usage, this graph also looks at video chats and texting. Which is interesting, because video calls aren’t even primary done on phones generally, rather they are usually done on computers. Of course texting is primarily done on phones, but we can’t simply conclude that the extra time that 15-24 year olds spent on texting, phone calls, and video calls is only including these things on phones.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: Hi, @James Molenhouse. You do bring up interesting points about what "phone use" means when phones do much more than text and call.

name: Logan AOSE
comment info: In the first graph, I notice that texting, phone calls, and video chats for all 4 groups increased, the 15-24 group increasing the most by 8 minutes. In the second graph, the 15-24 group was the only group that decreased their amount of time spent exercising while the other 3 groups increased. In the last graph, the 15-24 group was an outlier again, being the only group that increased their grooming time. The three other groups decreased substantially more. It's clear that the 15-24 group had very different results compared to the older groups. I wonder why the 15-24 group decreased their exercise over the last year while the older groups increased. Another question that relates to exercising is why the 15-24 group groomed themselves more while the older groups groomed less. It's an odd mix of the amount of self-care, decreasing exercise while increasing their grooming. These graphs relate to me and my community because everyone around me, including myself, has changed over the last year because of the pandemic. Using technology to communicate increased for everyone due to clear reasons like social distancing and attempting to stop the spread of COVID. Self-care over the past year differs for everyone I know. Some people have taken the time to rebuild themselves by working out or learning new things, while others struggled more mentally, causing them to not be as productive. A headline for this graph would be "Comparing the Use of Free Time with Each Generation"

name: Nathan C
comment info:
1. I notice that time spent on technology was the only category where everyone's time increased. 

2. - It's stressed that young people exercise a lot to stay healthy, so why aren't they exercising much during the pandemic? Is it because their only options are outdoor and outside activities? But then why wouldn't that have an effect on those older than them?

3. My community was already very online-centric, and this fact was only exasperated as the pandemic rolled in. This experience is similar to the left-most graph, where an already-online-related community only became more dependent on technology during the pandemic. 

4. Because of the pandemic, people of all ages spend more time using technology. Those who are ages 18-24 spend more of their time grooming, while also spending less on exercising; this development is most likely due to them needing to sacrifice *some* time for other unmentioned jobs. However, the times people of ages 25+ spent on grooming and exercising have undergone the opposite effects respectively. This increase in exercising is most likely due to the elderly needing to keep in shape, and the fact that 25 is not an old age whatsover; this once again leads to some of their time needing to be sacrificed, and grooming seems to be one of them. 
Title: "The Permanent Effects of the Pandemic on our Leisure Time"

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:
Hi, @Nathan C. Thanks for joining the conversation!

You made some good observations about the different activities and reasons for them. 

Your title says "permanent effects." Do you think these changes won't revert to the old patterns?

replies.name: N
replies.comment info: @Nathan C I do feel that younger people exercise more often usually. However, this was during a different time for many people. I feel that many young people felt less motivation to do so because we had so many other options of activities.

name: Colleen D
comment info:
1) All three graphs above depict similar results in that the age group is always the outlier. For example, in the first graph all of the age groups increased their time spent on their phones only by two to three minutes. Whereas the 15-24 age group increased their time spent on their phones by a whopping eight minutes. Although an increase in 8 minutes may not sound like much, comparatively speaking (with respect to the other age groups) it is a huge increase.  
2) Throughout the pandemic, technology because everyone's primary source of communication, work, etc. - so it is not unexpected that there would be an increase across the board of technology use. However, since everyone was using technology for everything it seemed like, I wonder why only the one age group increased by such a great amount. 
3) The information relates to my community and me because, throughout the pandemic, I noticed myself going on my phone and computer much more than I would have if things were normal. However, I also noticed that my parents were doing the same as well. This causes me to think: "If everyone was using technology for everything now, how is it that only my age group increased?" After thinking about this question, the results made sense. Although it is a bad habit, I feel that my age group was more likely to go on their phones while we were in online school whereas our parents, were focused on their work. 
4) How Different Generations Spent Their Time Before vs After the Pandemic

replies.name: M
replies.comment info:

I also spent more time online because it was the only way to contact people!

name: Ethan S.
comment info:
1) From these graphs, I noticed that the 15-24 age group had an 8-minute increase in texting, phone call, and video chat usage, but a 5-minute decrease in exercising. The two could be correlated, as people could be spending more time on their electronics, and less time being physically active. However, it was honestly surprising to see a 0.4-minute increase in time spent grooming, which does make sense, considering the greater amount of time on our hands.
2) Personally, I wonder why the 25-44, 45-64, and 65+ age groups experienced a pretty large decline in time spent grooming, but an increase in exercising. While grooming and exercising are both very necessary to personal health, I'd assume basic hygiene would be more of a priority.
3) As a person who falls between the 15-24 age group, the statistics specific to my age group relate to my own experience during quarantine. Being a remote student last year, I definitely spent more time texting and calling my friends, since we couldn't interact in-person as frequently. It was also difficult to motivate myself to go on runs, as I would regularly do during track or cross-country in previous years, but I still tried to go on walks a few times a week.
4) "Daily Life During the Pandemic: A New Age of Habit" - This headline refers to the various daily habits that have changed during the pandemic, with the relevant keywords "age" and "habit".

name: Eric
comment info:
Most striking in these graphs is the large contrast between those of age 15-24 and those aged 25+.  For example, while phone usage has increased for all age groups, younger populations are being much more dramatically affected by the onset of the pandemic.

The difference is much more noticeable in the other two graphs; while older age groups are rising in exercise time and lowering time dedicated to grooming, younger populations are experiencing lower levels of exercising and higher levels of grooming.

The age group highlighted in yellow is mostly delegated to students in high school and college. Thus, there is a large factor that creates a pandemic experience dramatically different than adults.

I wonder what pressures during the pandemic are being placed on students that compel them to overperform. They are spending more time glued to their phones and less time exercising. Moreover, an increase in grooming time implies that they are still expected to look fashionable to their online peers. What tasks are they doing on their phones that drains so much of their time?

As a high schooler, I witness the physical and mental deterioration of my fellow classmates, and understanding this data could be crucial for improving the mental health of students that are experiencing increasing levels of stress during the pandemic. 

Thus, my catchy headline: Student populations are placed under unrealistic expectations for increased online presence, draining their time and mental health.

replies.name: L
replies.comment info: @Eric With this data we should definitely find a way to help improve the mental health in teens, young adults, anyone really. The pandemic has left a huge impact on everyone.

name: Lance
comment info:
1) The 15-24 age group tended to stand out from the other populations somehow, with phone time increasing more dramatically, exercise decreasing where for others it decreased, and grooming increasing (if only marginally) where for others it decreased dramatically. Some of these make sense - younger generations might be more technologically up-to-date or more used to phone usage as part of normal life, and classes might interfere with time to go to the gym.

2) I do not understand why grooming increased/stayed the same, especially when all other age groups' habits decreased so dramatically. If anything, I would think that grooming would decrease, since classes were primarily virtual.

3) Increased time on the Internet and exposures to all different types of content can be debilitating for many adolescents' upbringing. In addition, increased screen time as a habit itself might affect work ethic, attention span, etc.

4) "Routine Disturbance: Pandemic Habits Across Age Groups." This title can be read two ways, since "routine" is both an adjective and a noun, and therefore describes both dramatic shifts, or disturbances, in previous lifestyles, and regular, reoccuring disturbance in the present pandemic lifestyle. While over time these changes are observable and obvious, in the moment, they are just another part of life; the "new normal" was a lack of any form of normallity.

name: Brian
comment info:
I notice that the four age groups differ in their average non-work and non-school time spent per day, and that all four age groups have been drastically affected by some factor (presumably the Covid pandemic). As a 17 year old, I notice the changes in the 15-24 age group the most: increased time spent texting/calling/video chatting, decreased time exercising, and a slight change in time spent grooming (whereas the other age groups have spent much less time grooming). While the other three age groups tend to move in a similar fashion, 15-24 year olds seem to be a bit more "independent".

I wonder how these statistics were gathered. What is the sample size and was the data collected from a representative population reflective of the country? Probably the most striking statistic is the increase in grooming time for 15-24 year olds, while an opposite change can be observed in the other age groups. Why is this? For the second graph, does the data take into account mandatory virtual PE classes?

Obviously, these statistics are very relevant to all people in the US, whose school and work have been affected by the pandemic. The first graph resonates well with my own personal experiences, as my friends and I have spent much more time video chatting compared to 2019.

Headline: Pandemic Highlights Striking Generational Divide

name: Sean
comment info:
Younger People Naturally More Lazy?

A trend seen is the increase in time spent on electronics, and a decrease in the time spent exercising for people ages 15-24. In comparison, while older generations spent more time on electronics as well, their increase was significantly lower. They also tended to exercise more during the pandemic than ages 15-24.  Nobody cares about grooming, so we ignore the fact that the younger generation actually spent more time grooming themselves. 

Screen time went up significantly for my age range due to the focus on virtual schooling and assignments, and the primary way to connect with people was also mainly over our devices as opposed to hanging out irl. And naturally, given the opportunity, the younger generation defaulted to being lazier than before. : )

name: Faith Caldwell
comment info:
Did We Change For The Better Or For The Worst? 

I notice that for every age group, the time spent on texting, phone calls, and video chats increased over the course of the pandemic. The exercise results vary; people of younger ages, 15-24, decreased their exercise whereas the adults, ages 45+ increased their exercise. For the most part, grooming decreased. I wonder if this is all due to the pandemic. I also wonder if students decreased their exercise due to mental health reasons and/or being outside of school, where there is no physical education provided to them. As for the older ages, I wonder if they exercised more because most were working from home and had more free time. I wonder if people exercised because they wanted to better themselves or maybe for weight loss. I wonder if the use of technology increased because most of the population had an increase in spare time and time spent at home. Finally, I wonder if the decrease in grooming occurred because there was an increase in isolation amongst the community. As previously stated, this all relates back to the community because, at the times of May through December 2020, a worldwide pandemic occurred where everyone was forced to quarantine. name: Brynn
comment info: Today, this graph is displaying the average amount of time different age groups spent doing a variety activities in 2019 vs. 2020. The categories: texting, phone calls and video chats, exercising, and grooming. For the first category, every age groups minutes spent using their phone increased from 2019 until 2020, some as much as an 8 min increase. This can be attributed to one factor: COVID-19 pandemic. With kids and adults staying home all day, it's easier to find time to text, play games, etc. Also, without having the constant contact with peers in the workplace or school, people had to communicate through the internet with texting and calling. The next graph shows a decrease and increase in exercise from 2019 to 2020. The 15-24 year olds had a steady decline starting at 35 minutes of exercise a day, and ending with only 30. Given that with everyone being home you should have more free time, this statistic can only be attributed to the people actually wanting to exercise. Things like gym class and sports sort of forced exercise on this age category, and without it people chose not to exercise. The 25-44 and 65+ categories actually had a steady increase of 4 more minutes of exercise a day. The opposite occurred here, so when given more time, 25 to 65 year olds use it to exercise. The last statistic is a scary one...for since people were not leaving the house, it appears as if the time spent grooming was shortened entirely except for the 15-24 who barely spent more time.

name: Giancarlo B

Title: Changes in People's Time Spent during the COVID-19 Pandemic

The first graph shows how the pandemic caused a substantial increase in the use of electronics in people aged 15-24, while every other age group saw a minor increase of 2-3 minutes. This is likely due to people aged 15-24 having to attend online classes for either high school or college instead of having in person classes. The second graph saw an increase in every age group except 15-24, who saw a -5 decrease in excerise. Finally, every age group besides 15-24 saw a major decrease in time spent grooming. 

Altogether, these 3 graphs show the change in how each age group spent their time. 15-24 responded best to the change to using electronics during pandemic, as they saw the biggest change out of all 3 charts. People aged 25+ saw a minor increase in electronics but spent more time excerising and way less time grooming themselves. 15-24 did the best job of keeping themselves clean

name: Alexa AOSE
comment info:
Title: How did society's habits change during the pandemic?

In the first graph, the use of electronics including texting, phone calls and video chats increase significantly amongst all age groups compared from 2019 to 2020. In the second graph, the amount of exercise of individuals ages 15-24 decreased versus the slight increase in other age groups. In the last graph, people aged 45-64 decrease grooming significantly along with those aged 25-44 and 65+. People aged 15-24 saw no change. 

These three graphs document the habits of four different age groups before and during the pandemic. While younger people responded better to technology and communication devices, they did not respond as well to exercise but kept their grooming habits.   Other age groups did not respond as well to technology and struggled to maintain their grooming habits, but kept up their exercise regimen. 

I wonder why exercise decreased for younger people, considering they're the most physically abled group of people.

name: Ty Robnett
comment info:
COVID and Its Effects

I noticed that the younger age group were the outliers of the whole graph, and that the younger age group had the most significant changes out of all of the other age groups, such as the most texting, most decrease in exercise, and the most increase in grooming.
I wonder why the three older age groups stayed relatively the same, although there is a 40 year difference and the statistics stayed very similar for all three.
These graphs relate to me and my community because I feel that I started to text more between 2019 and 2020, and that I exercised less during the pandemic, and finally I started taking more care of myself and how I looked. This relates to my community because most of my community are people my age so they have similar insights as me.
In the first graph, all age groups had an increase in texting, phone calls, and video chats during 2019 and 2020. This graph could be called Digital Distractions. In the second graph, age groups from 25+ had an increase in exercise, however ages 15-24 were the only age group to decrease in exercise use time. This graph could be called Exercising Options. In the last graph, ages 25+ had a decrease in grooming while the only age group to have an increase in grooming were ages 15-24. This graph could be called Body Over Mind.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Ty Robnett --

Love our headlines for the individual graphs.  If you were to make headlines by age group, what would it be for 15 – 24 year olds and for 65+ year olds?

How did you determine that “the younger age group had the most significant changes out of all of the other age groups?”  If you wanted to do it mathematically, you could add the absolute values of the changes for each age group.  Or, you could use the percentage changes.  (Be careful of the units.)  Lots more to notice and wonder.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @TJ RS1 Nelson 6th --

Thank you for compiling your responses.  

You ask, “How’d did NYT get the data?”  The answer is under the graph.  The New York Times always gives the source of it graph data.  If you search the source and add the word “methodology,” you will find your answer.

And, you ask, “Why weren’t kids less than 15 polled?”  Though there may be laws about surveying minors and their privacy, how reliable do you think the data would be?

You may also want to take another look at the y-axes.  How do the numbers relate to your perceptions of which age group and activity changed the most?
Looking forward to your responses next week.

name: Megan S.
comment info:
PART 1 OF 2
1. In these graphs, I notice that all age groups in the texting, phone calls, and video chat chart same trend at different variations of steepness. How do you compare to the changes in free time for most people due to the pandemic? 
What different age groups do during their free time ever since the pandemic
Pandemic Pastimes

name: Amy
comment info:
1. I noticed that the 15-24 age group had the greatest increase with time spent texting, phone calls, and video chats. But the actual increase wasn't that much, only 8 minutes more. 
 
I noticed that students (ages 15-24) spent less time exercising in 2020 compared to 2019. I am assuming that this would be because they weren’t involved in school sports during COVID and that would account for much of their exercise time.
 
I noticed that the 45-64 age group spent less time grooming in 2020. I am guessing that this is because many of them weren’t going into work and were working from home instead. Another reason could be because many salons were closed at this time.

2. I wonder if the amount of time is accurate for the first graph. The amount of time spent texting, calling, and on video chats seems low, especially for the 15-24 age group. 

3. I feel that the data is fairly accurate in showing trends that I saw in my community and amongst my friends and family. More time was spent trying to connect to people using electronics and less time was spent grooming because people weren’t leaving their houses.  

4. COVID changes our daily habits

replies.comment info:
HI, @Amy --

I, too, wonder about the time spent texting, making phone calls and on video chats.  Can you think of a reason for such low number of minutes?  
To find out about how the data were collected, search online for “BLS American Time Use Survey methodology.”  It is a full explanation of how the data was collected and analyzed.

name: Neelu Sinha
comment info:
I notice that Texting etc. for 15-24 group increased 133% while for the other groups it only increased 40-42%. Exercising went down about 15% for the 15-24 group and for the others it went up about 30%. The grooming for 15-24 went up very slightly 1% but for the 25-44 and 65+ group declined about 10%. For the group 45-64 it declined 16%. So, texting etc. was far by the biggest change! Grooming was the least! Exercising was in the middle!

I wonder if the pandemic will actually make us more communicative, compassionate, and healthier! 

Will make everyone a changed person and create better, -cohesive communities.

Life is all about learning!

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Neelu Sinha --

Great that you calculated the percentage changes to determine which changes were most significant.  

If you recreate these graphs with the three having the same x-axes, you can determine the most significant changes without making the calculations.  How is that?  The advantage of slope charts!
